```{r, include=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(dplyr)
```

TIL I learned that you can filter on conditions for more than one variable at a time using `if_any` or `if_all`.

<center>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Just to add to the confusion (üòÖ) I think you still do use it for mutate but not for filter?<br><br>‚ö†Ô∏è Using `across()` in `filter()` is deprecated, use `if_any()` or `if_all()`.</p>&mdash; Lucy D‚ÄôAgostino McGowan (@LucyStats) <a href="https://twitter.com/LucyStats/status/1506026504618221579?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">March 21, 2022</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> 
</center>

Turns out that `across()` is only for selecting functions (like `summarize()` and `mutate()`).

You use `if_any()` vs. `if_all()` depending if you need to match some vs. all columns.

`if_any()`:

```{r}
mtcars %>%
  as_tibble() %>%
  mutate(across(everything(), as.integer)) %>%
  filter(if_any(contains("m"), ~ . == 0))
```

`if_all()`:

```{r}
mtcars %>%
  as_tibble() %>%
  mutate(across(everything(), as.integer)) %>%
  filter(if_any(everything(), ~ . == 0))
```

Any tidyselect usage is kosher inside `if_*()` just like inside `across()`, so they work very similarly.

**Thanks to Gustavo E. for his explanation.**
